title: 110_hr7316
content: The Act may be cited as the "Limitation on Nuclear Cooperation with the United Arab Emirates Act of 2008". Definitions are provided in Section 2. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate. The term "Government of the United Arab Emirates" includes the government of any subdivision, agency, or instrumentality of the UAE. The term "Government of Iran" includes the government of any subdivision of Iran and any agency or instrumentality of the Government of Iran, defined as an agency or instrumentality of a foreign state as per section 1603(b) of title 28, United States Code. In the context of the Government of Iran, the terms "national of the United Arab Emirates" and "national of Iran" are defined as citizens or legal entities organized under the respective country's laws. Restriction on nuclear cooperation with the United Arab Emirates. Restriction on nuclear cooperation between the United States and the United Arab Emirates under the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, requiring certification from the President before any agreement can enter into force. Additionally, no license may be issued for the export of nuclear material, equipment, or technology to the UAE under such agreement for any fiscal year after a certain date. The Energy Act of 1954 requires certification from the President before issuing a license for nuclear cooperation with the United Arab Emirates. The UAE must take actions to prevent the transfer of goods, services, or technology to Iran, and there should be no cooperation in this regard for the preceding 12-month period. The Energy Act of 1954 mandates presidential certification for nuclear cooperation with the United Arab Emirates. The UAE must prevent any collaboration with Iran, Iranian nationals, or Iranian-controlled entities. The United Arab Emirates must terminate all cooperation with Iran, prevent future collaboration, and prosecute any nationals involved. Additionally, they must not engage in activities that violate the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996. The United Arab Emirates has implemented export control measures and legislative actions to target networks supporting terrorist organizations. The term "goods, services, or technology" is defined in this section. The term "goods, services, or technology" refers to items listed in the Nuclear Suppliers Group Guidelines and the Missile Technology Control Regime. The curr_chunk discusses various lists of controlled items related to biological, chemical, and toxic substances, as well as dual-use goods and technologies. The curr_chunk discusses controlled items listed in various regulations, including the United States Munitions List and the Commerce Control List, as well as goods, services, and technology not listed but prohibited for export to Iran. The curr_chunk discusses the exclusion of goods, services, or technology related to the Bushehr nuclear power reactor from export restrictions to Iran. Requirement for congressional approval of agreements for peaceful nuclear cooperation. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to require congressional approval for subsequent nuclear cooperation agreements with other nations. The amendments include changes to the language regarding effective cooperation and the procedures for approval by Congress. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to require congressional approval for subsequent nuclear cooperation agreements with other nations, with a deadline for submission of a nuclear proliferation assessment statement to the relevant committees in Congress. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to require the President to inform congressional committees about any new or amended agreements for peaceful nuclear cooperation before announcing them. Consultation with the committees must begin within 15 days of negotiations initiation and continue monthly until the negotiations are concluded.
